title: The Anti-Capitalist Case for Standards
text:
This is an interesting read from the MIT Press Reader: The Anti-Capitalist Case for Standards. Things like this can sometimes seem self-evident, but it’s important to point to areas where collaboration, particularly across national borders, has taken place outside the paradigm of profit making.
N.B.: comments are enabled on all posts. Scroll down to see the comment box—you’ll need a GitHub account!

title: The Tricontinental
text:
The Tricontinental Institute for Social Research describes itself as “an international institute guided by popular movements and organisations [which seeks] to build a bridge between academic production and political and social movements in order to promote critical thinking and stimulate debates and research with an emancipatory perspective that serves the people’s aspirations.” It’s a resource I return to frequently.
You can read their latest newsletter here: Twenty-Five Days of Debt-Service Payments Could Emancipate African Women from 40 Billion Hours of Water Harvesting: The Eleventh Newsletter (2025)
I also really enjoyed this article about the environmental remediation efforts in China since 2013: Reviving Erhai Lake

title: Building a World Without Carbon
text:
According to Costa Samaras, Director of the Wilton E. Scott Institute for Energy Innovation at Carnegie Mellon University, building a world without carbon will require us to think in terms of “megaprojects”. Writing for the Roosevelt Institute, Dr. Samaras notes that in order to meet a target date of 2050 for net zero carbon emissions, a heroic effort will still be needed. We’ve made a start on the transition, but it remains to be seen what the effects of this administration will be. They’re unlikely to be good.
You can follow Dr. Samaras on Bluesky.

title: The Participatory Budgeting Project
text:

title: Ancient DNA
text:

title: About Me
text:

Christine is my favorite person, obviously. If you want to know more about her, you can listen to our interview on Story Corps (April 2025) if you want to hear us in an unstructured conversation. She is a healthcare defense litigator, law professor, and occasional constitutional scholar.
